entry.title: Protected: The Longest Journey
entry.summary: There is no excerpt because this is a protected post. The post Protected: The Longest Journey appeared first on The Atavist Magazine.

entry.title: Reservoirs of Resistance
entry.summary: By studying the millennia-old arms race between soil-dwelling microbes, scientists can pre-empt antibiotic resistance before it emerges in people.

entry.title: Graduate Student Solves Classic Problem About the Limits of Addition
entry.summary: A new proof illuminates the hidden patterns that emerge when addition becomes impossible. The post Graduate Student Solves Classic Problem About the Limits of Addition first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: For Algorithms, a Little Memory Outweighs a Lot of Time
entry.summary: One computer scientist’s “stunning” proof is the first progress in 50 years on one of the most famous questions in computer science. The post For Algorithms, a Little Memory Outweighs a Lot of Time first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: Keeping Ahead of Contagion
entry.summary: We have the technology to detect airborne pathogens in real time. Now we must use it.

entry.title: ‘Turbocharged’ Mitochondria Power Birds’ Epic Migratory Journeys
entry.summary: Slight changes in the number, shape, efficiency and interconnectedness of organelles in the cells of flight muscles provide extra energy for birds’ continent-spanning feats. The post ‘Turbocharged’ Mitochondria Power Birds’ Epic Migratory Journeys first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: New ‘Superdiffusion’ Proof Probes the Mysterious Math of Turbulence
entry.summary: Turbulence is a notoriously difficult phenomenon to study. Mathematicians are now starting to untangle it at its smallest scales. The post New ‘Superdiffusion’ Proof Probes the Mysterious Math of Turbulence first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: Model Organisms Are Not Static
entry.summary: A research study reveals that some vertebrate genomes mutate 40-times faster than others.

entry.title: How Did Geometry Create Modern Physics?
entry.summary: Geometry may have its origins thousands of years ago in ancient land surveying, but it has also had a surprising impact on modern physics. In the latest episode of The Joy of Why, Yang-Hui He explores geometry’s evolution and its future potential through AI. The post How Did Geometry Create Modern Physics? first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: How the Universe Differs From Its Mirror Image
entry.summary: From living matter to molecules to elementary particles, the world is made of “chiral” objects that differ from their reflected forms. The post How the Universe Differs From Its Mirror Image first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: Seven Wonders of Biology
entry.summary: A decades-old essay offers newfound appreciation for progress.

entry.title: How Much Information is in DNA?
entry.summary: Answering this question may seem straightforward, but actually requires an odyssey through information theory and molecular biology.

entry.title: Are you more likely to die on your birthday?
entry.summary: Are you more likely to die on your birthday? Yes.

entry.title: Making the Centrifuge
entry.summary: The modern centrifuge was first designed for milkfat separation in the dairy industry. Today, it is ubiquitous in research laboratories. To whom do we owe its astonishing versatility?

entry.title: A Brief History of GFP
entry.summary: How a chance discovery in bioluminescent jellyfish led to one of the most transformative tools in modern biology: green fluorescent protein.

entry.title: Traffic Fatalities Are a Choice
entry.summary: America’s roads are more dangerous than those of almost every country in the developed world. We know how to change that.

entry.title: Reports of the Death of California High-Speed Rail Have Been Greatly Exaggerated
entry.summary: Building a high-speed rail between Los Angeles and San Francisco was never going to be easy — but the critics who write it off are missing the real source of the project’s struggles.

entry.title: Can We Trust Social Science Yet?
entry.summary: Everyone likes the idea of evidence-based policy, but it’s hard to realize it when our most reputable social science journals are still publishing poor quality research.

entry.title: Does AI Progress Have a Speed Limit?
entry.summary: A conversation about the factors that might slow down the pace of AI development, what could happen next, and whether we’ll be able to see it coming.

entry.title: China’s Clinical Trial Boom
entry.summary: In 2017, there were just over 600 clinical trials initiated in China. By 2023, that number was nearly 2,000. How can American companies kick off a similar boom?

entry.title: All That Glitters
entry.summary: His alleged victims say he bribed New York Police Department officials, stole millions in diamonds, and persuaded Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Kim Kardashian to shill for a scam cryptocurrency. So why is Jona Rechnitz still free? The post All That Glitters appeared first on The Atavist Magazine.

entry.title: Does Abundance Start at Home?
entry.summary: Kelsey Piper and Jasmine Sun talk about microschools, whether localism is the enemy of Abundance, and why Chinese bureaucrats are like Growth PMs.

entry.title: Eulogy to the Obits
entry.summary: With a litany of gene therapies and longevity medicine staving off biological death, those paid to write about it must reimagine their craft.

entry.title: Can Plants Really “See”?
entry.summary: Some researchers claim that a Chilean vine can mimic the leaves of a plastic houseplant thanks to a form of primitive vision. But extraordinary claims require equally extraordinary evidence.

entry.title: The Pour-igin of Species
entry.summary: We try to predict the price and quality of a bottle of wine based on the animal on the label.

entry.title: The Magic of Fast Feedback Loops
entry.summary: Why biologists should operate with a sense of urgency.

entry.title: Recipe for a Cell
entry.summary: While we know how to break organisms down to their constituent parts, even at the atomic level, building them from scratch remains difficult.

entry.title: On Prions and Protein Design
entry.summary: Prions are extremely resilient, infectious proteins. Studying their shape-shifting abilities could reveal lessons for how proteins fold at a molecular level, helping scientists design better ones.

entry.title: Where Babies Come From
entry.summary: It’s more complicated than you may think.

entry.title: The Origins of Adjuvants
entry.summary: More than a century after the invention of vaccines, a veterinarian stumbled across a technique to boost their efficacy in an unlikely way — by observing wounded horses.

entry.title: The Generational Legacy of Samples in Music
entry.summary: We trace musical DNA from the classical "Hall of the Mountain King" to 2pac's "Hit Em Up."

entry.title: The First Day
entry.summary: Asterisk Magazine covers science, emerging technologies, economics, politics, culture, global health, threats to human development and flourishing.

entry.title: The Future of American Foreign Aid
entry.summary: USAID has been slashed, and it is unclear what shape its successor will take. How might American foreign assistance be restructured to maintain critical functions? And how should we think about its future?

entry.title: The Nobel Duel
entry.summary: A cautionary tale about the competitive pressures of scientific research, and how they alter the course of history.

entry.title: What Limits a Cell’s Size?
entry.summary: Two physical constraints help explain why cells are so tiny: surface area-to-volume ratios and diffusion. The first article in our new Data Series.

entry.title: The Eagle Hunters of Kyrgyzstan
entry.summary: In the mountains of Central Asia, a Small group of outdoorsmen are keeping an ancient tradition alive. The post The Eagle Hunters of Kyrgyzstan appeared first on The Atavist Magazine.

entry.title: A Brief History of the Miracle Bacterium
entry.summary: Serratia marcescens, a pathogen with an uncanny resemblance to blood, has had an outsized influence on modern science.

entry.title: The Balloon that Fell from the Sky
entry.summary: Fifteen teams lifted off from Switzerland in gas ballooning’s most audacious race. Three days later, two of them drifted into Belarusian airspace—but only one would survive. The post The Balloon that Fell from the Sky appeared first on The Atavist Magazine.

entry.title: Meet the Humans Building AI Scientists
entry.summary: A look inside FutureHouse, a nonprofit research institute in San Francisco.

entry.title: What we can learn from watching reality stars apologize
entry.summary: What we can learn from watching reality stars apologize.

entry.title: Healing My Family’s Future
entry.summary: How genetics and IVF empowered our family to leave cancer behind.

entry.title: Announcing Issue 06: Blood-Red Microbes, AI Scientists, Nobel Duels
entry.summary: Plus: A partnership with Astera Institute and our first job posting.

entry.title: Onomatopoeia Odyssey
entry.summary: Analyzing animal onomatopoeia across languages can demystify how we shape sound into meaning.

entry.title: We Can, Must, and Will Simulate Nematode Brains
entry.summary: Scientists have spent over 25 years trying — and failing — to build computer simulations of the smallest brain we know. Today, we finally have the tools to pull it off.

entry.title: Greening the Solar System
entry.summary: A future where life flourishes beyond Earth is closer than you think. How, precisely, will we get there?

entry.title: Are AIs People?
entry.summary: Every year, AI models get better at thinking. Could they possibly be capable of feeling? And if they are, how would we know?

entry.title: The Science of Woo
entry.summary: A conversation about neuroscience, meditation, and the many paths to insight.

entry.title: The Middle Ages
entry.summary: Follow hundreds of kids as they navigate their trecherous middle school years.
